709426f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue and Broadway, north from W. 33rd Street, showing the "El" tracks upon the numerical Avenue. To the right is the diagonal Broadway. 34th Street is where the Broadway Tabernacle appears. The distinctive Herald Building is north of 35th Street, separating Broadway (left) from 6th Avenue. At the left is the southbound platform obstructing the sign that identifies Jim Corbett's Saloon. The latter was a world's heavyweight boxing champion.
1899
Gift of Urbrock Collection

720394f-a.text:
Broadway and the west side of Sixth Avenue, north from 34th Street. The centre building, fronting on Broadway and Sixth Ave, was formerly the Seventy-First Regiment Armory, and is now the New York Herald Building. Later, in 1928, it will be cut in half; the narrower, southern half will remain, and in 1936 will house the Rogers Peet Company. The 35th Street half, however, will be demolished and replaced by the 24-story Herald Square Building. In the background is the recently built Times Building, which has caused the name of Longacre Square to be changed to Times Square
About 1905.

717396f.text:
Broadway, north from 33rd Street, showing also Sixth Avenue, west side, from 33rd to 30th Streets. Sak's 34th Street store is in the left foreground with Macy's department store above it. In the center is the Herald Building. In 1928 it will be cut in half, and the northern, or rear portion demolished, with the Herald Square Building rising in its site.
In the center background is the Hotel Normandie, and in slightly left-center background is the Metropolitan Opera House. Dominating the skyline is the new building of the New York Times.
Ewing Galloway  1909

712050f.text:
43-47 West 33rd Street, north side, east of Broadway.
1914.

709425f-a.text:
6th Avenue and West intersection and 33rd Street. (Before Reconstruction).
President Borough of Manhattan
March 21, 1920.

717397f-a.text:
Saks - 34th Street, a large department store, Broadway,
west side, from 34th to 33rd Streets.
About 1921.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

720392f-a.text:
At the intersection of Broadway and Sixth Ave., at West 34th Street. On the left is Broadway, north from and including West 34th Street. Also shown is Sixth Ave., (Sixth Ave., Elevated) north from, but not including 34th Street. Rogers Peet Building is shown on West 35th Street, north side, from Broadway to Sixth Ave. Macy's Dept., Store is barely discernible on Broadway. (Building with clock) The N. Y. Times Building and the Astor Hotel are shown in the background, at the head of Broadway.
February 7, 1927.
New York Edison Company.

720145f-a.text:
Greeley Square, a triangular plot at the convergence of Sixth Ave., and Broadway, at West 33rd Street. Across the square appears Broadway at the S.E. corner of West 33rd Street. This is under the care of the Dept.
of Parks.
April 26, 1934.
Views 1, 2
P. L. Sperr.

709427f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, at a. 33rd Street, showing the northbound platform of the cith Avenue "El" outlined against the Hotel McAlpin. Note at the left the approaching soutbound train. This one of the last to run over these tracks as April of this year will see the complete demolition of this line.
March 1939
Wm. Herries

709432f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue and Broadway, north from West 34th Street, showing the subway construction shaft occupying the former park site that was identified as Herald Souare. This received its name from the newspaper plant above. One-half of this site still contaias the low original building, the remainder being improved with the
towering Herald Suuare Building.
Broadway is on the left and 6th Avenue on the right. The former thoroughfare is the vantage point for the photographer in view 2 and from which he is viewing north-eastward towards the office building at the N. E. corner of 6th Avenue and W. 35th Street.
View 1: March 29, 1939
View 2: February 18, 1939
P. L. Sperr
